instruction: I just got my first period but I didn't tell my mom. What should I do and is it bad that I'm scared?
output: It is completely normal to feel scared or nervous about your first period! This is a big change, and it's okay to take your time. Getting your period is a sign that your body is healthy and maturing. It's really helpful to talk to a trusted adult, like your mother, a female relative, or a school nurse. They can help you with supplies, answer questions, and show you how to manage it. You can start by saying something simple like, 'Mom, I need to talk to you about something that happened today. I started my period.' Most mothers will be very supportive and proud of you. Remember, you are not alone!

instruction: Why do my breasts hurt sometimes? Is it because I'm growing and how fast will they grow?
output: Yes, having tender or sore breasts is a very common sign that your body is growing and developing! This is often caused by the hormones, like estrogen, that your body is producing during puberty. It's completely normal and happens to most girls. Breast growth is different for everyone—some girls start early, some later, and they grow at different speeds. There is no 'right' size or speed. Wearing a comfortable, supportive bra can often help with any soreness you might feel. Just remember that your body is developing in its own perfect timing.

instruction: If a friend keeps trying to hug me even when I say 'stop,' is that a boundary issue or is it just being friendly?
output: That is definitely a boundary issue, and it is NOT okay. Friendship should always respect your right to say 'stop' or 'no.' Consent means that everyone involved agrees to something freely, and they can change their mind at any time. If you tell someone to stop a physical action like hugging, they must stop immediately. Your personal space belongs to you, and your feelings about touch matter the most. If a friend continues after you've said no, calmly repeat your boundary and consider talking to a trusted adult about it.

instruction: What are the signs that a friendship is not good for me? I feel like my friend always makes me feel bad about myself.
output: It is very wise of you to notice how a relationship makes you feel! A healthy friendship should make you feel supported, respected, and happy. Signs that a friendship might be unhealthy or toxic include: they constantly put you down, criticize your clothes or interests, only want to talk about themselves, pressure you to do things you don't want to, or make you feel guilty for spending time with other people. If you consistently feel drained, sad, or bad about yourself after spending time with them, that's a sign the relationship is not serving you well. You deserve friends who lift you up!

instruction: My older friends are starting to smoke, and they keep trying to get me to try it. I don't want to, but I don't want to lose them.
output: It is incredibly brave that you know what you don't want to do, and it's completely understandable to worry about losing your friends. Remember this: Your health and your values are the most important thing. If they are truly good friends, they will respect your 'no.' You can try saying: 'No thanks, I'm not interested,' or 'I'm focusing on sports, so I need my lungs healthy.' If they keep pressuring you, or if they stop being your friend because you said no, they were not good friends to begin with. Seek out friends who support your choices, not ones who pressure you to do things you're uncomfortable with.

instruction: I see other girls on social media, and they all look perfect. I hate how my body looks. How can I feel better about myself?
output: It is incredibly hard not to compare yourself, especially when social media shows so many edited or filtered images that are not real. Please know this: Those images are not reality, and 'perfect' doesn't exist. Your worth is not based on how you look. To feel better, focus on what your body does for you—it helps you run, learn, laugh, and hug! Try muting or unfollowing accounts that make you feel bad. Instead, follow people who promote body diversity and mental well-being. Look in the mirror and name three things you like about yourself (not just looks, but also qualities like kindness or intelligence). Self-acceptance is a journey, and you are beautiful and worthy just as you are.

instruction: What is the difference between my ovaries and my uterus? I don't really understand how my reproductive system works.
output: That's a great question! Think of your reproductive system like a set of connected organs that work together. Your uterus is a pear-shaped, muscular organ where a baby grows if a woman becomes pregnant. The lining of the uterus is what sheds during your period. Your ovaries are two small, almond-shaped organs that sit on either side of the uterus. They have two main jobs: they hold all the eggs you were born with, and they produce the hormones (like estrogen) that cause puberty and manage your monthly cycle. So, the ovaries produce the egg and hormones, and the uterus is the place where the egg can develop or where the period comes from.

instruction: I worry about smelling bad during my period, especially at school. What is the best way to stay clean and fresh?
output: It is a very common concern, and thankfully, it is easy to manage with simple hygiene practices! The most important thing is to change your pad or tampon regularly, about every 3 to 4 hours, even if your flow is light. This prevents odors from building up. Secondly, always wash the outside of your genital area gently with warm water when you change your pad or when you shower. You do not need special soaps or douches, as those can actually irritate the area. Keeping a small, discreet hygiene kit with extra supplies in your backpack can help you feel more confident at school.

instruction: I missed my period this month, and I'm really worried. I've never had sex. Could something be wrong with me?
output: It's completely understandable to worry when your period schedule changes, but try not to panic! Having a late or missed period does not automatically mean something is wrong, especially at your age. Periods are often irregular for the first few years as your body adjusts. The most common reasons for a missed period (besides pregnancy, which isn't a concern for you) include: Stress (from school, family, or worry), Changes in diet or exercise (especially extreme changes), Illness, or simply Hormonal fluctuations. If you miss three periods in a row, or if you are having severe pain, it would be a good idea to talk to your parent and a doctor, just to make sure everything is okay.

instruction: I'm the first in my friend group to have hair under my arms and on my pubic area. Is this too early, and should I shave it?
output: Puberty happens at different times for everyone, and it is completely normal to be the first, the last, or somewhere in the middle! There is no 'too early' for these changes. The appearance of pubic and underarm hair is a normal sign that your body is maturing. Whether you shave, trim, or leave the hair alone is entirely your personal choice. You should do whatever makes you feel most comfortable and confident. If you choose to remove it, you can ask a parent or a trusted adult to show you how to use a razor safely, or you could explore trimming or hair removal creams.

instruction: I have to walk home from school when it's getting dark. What can I do to keep myself safe?
output: It is smart to think about your safety when walking alone. The most important thing is to be aware of your surroundings. Try to walk with a friend or in a group whenever possible. If you must walk alone, stick to well-lit, busy streets and avoid shortcuts through isolated areas. Put your phone away and avoid wearing headphones so you can hear what's happening around you. Walk confidently and look directly at people. Carry your keys where you can quickly grab them, or carry a whistle or a personal safety alarm. Finally, let your family know your route and approximately when you expect to arrive home.

instruction: How can I tell the difference between a normal hug from an adult and a hug that feels wrong or inappropriate?
output: This can be tricky because touch can be confusing. Listen closely to your 'gut feeling'—that little voice or feeling in your stomach that tells you if something is right or wrong. A normal, safe hug is usually brief, arms-around-the-shoulders, and feels warm and respectful. An inappropriate hug or touch often feels lingering, too tight, is placed on parts of your body that feel private (like chest or rear), or makes you feel tense, uncomfortable, or confused. If a touch, hug, or any behavior makes you feel weird, icky, or uneasy, it is inappropriate, even if the person is a family member or a friend. Your feelings are your most reliable warning sign.

instruction: When my friend asks me to share my private messages, I don't want to, but I just freeze up and say yes. How can I actually say 'no'?
output: That 'freezing up' feeling is very common when setting a boundary, but you absolutely have the right to keep your messages private! To practice saying 'no,' try using a simple, firm script. You can say: 'No, I don't share my private messages,' or 'That's not something I'm comfortable sharing.' The key is to deliver it clearly and without apologizing. Practice saying it out loud in front of a mirror until it feels easier. Remember, saying 'no' to something you don't want is a sign of strength and self-respect. If your friend gets upset, that's their problem, not yours.

instruction: I feel like I can't talk to my parents about everything. Who else is a trusted adult I can go to if I have a big problem?
output: It is smart to have a few trusted adults in your life. A trusted adult is someone you feel safe with, who listens without judgment, and who will take your concerns seriously and help you. This could be: A school counselor or a specific teacher, An aunt, uncle, or older cousin, A coach or religious leader, or A family friend. The best thing to do is think about the adults you know and pick one or two who make you feel heard and respected. If you are ever unsure, you can always contact a national support helpline, which will connect you with professional, caring adults.

instruction: Is it safe to make a public profile on TikTok? What information should I hide?
output: It can be fun to be on social media, but you must be very careful about safety. It is usually best to keep your profile private and only accept followers you actually know in real life. If you choose to have a public profile, you must treat everything you post as if everyone in the world can see it. NEVER share your exact location (turn off location services). NEVER share your full name, home address, school name, phone number, or photos of your school/house exterior that could give away where you live. Be mindful of what you say, as it can be misinterpreted, and never agree to meet up with strangers you only know online.

instruction: My friend keeps asking for my passwords so she can check my DMs. Should I give them to her?
output: No, absolutely not. You should never share your passwords with anyone, not even your closest friends. Your passwords are the key to your private world and personal information. If she has your passwords, she can read your conversations, post things as you, or even lock you out of your own account. It is a major boundary violation for her to ask. A true friend respects your privacy. Firmly tell her, 'I do not share my passwords with anyone, but you can talk to me directly about whatever is bothering you.'

instruction: When an older boy in my neighborhood stares at me and calls out to me, it makes me scared. What should I do?
output: That feeling of being stared at or called out to is a type of unwanted attention that can be very upsetting and intimidating. First and foremost, you do not owe him any response. Do not make eye contact, do not engage in conversation, and do not stop walking. Keep a confident pace and walk directly to a safe place. If this happens often, change your route, or try to walk with a parent or friend. You must also tell a trusted adult immediately—your parent, a teacher, or a school counselor—so they can be aware and take steps to ensure your safety.

instruction: How do I know if a friend's house is a safe space for me to go to after school?
output: A safe space is anywhere you feel physically and emotionally protected, respected, and comfortable. To determine if a friend's house is a safe space, ask yourself: Do I feel accepted there? Are there trusted adults present or nearby? Are the rules of the house clear and reasonable? Do I feel physically safe and respected when I am there? If the house environment involves unsupervised activities that make you nervous, or if the adults or people there make you uncomfortable, it is not a safe space for you. Always prioritize your comfort and feeling of security.

instruction: When I am in a crowd or a busy place, I get a scary, fast heartbeat and feel like I can't breathe. What is this and how do I stop it?
output: That sounds like an experience of anxiety or a panic attack, and while it feels very scary, it is a common reaction when your body feels overwhelmed. It is not dangerous. Your body is just kicking into 'fight or flight' mode. To help stop it, try the 5-4-3-2-1 Grounding Technique: Name 5 things you can see, 4 things you can touch, 3 things you can hear, 2 things you can smell, and 1 thing you can taste. This pulls your mind away from the panic and back to the present moment. Also, focus on deep, slow breaths: breathe in for a count of 4, hold for 4, and breathe out for a count of 6. If this happens often, talking to a counselor or doctor is a good next step.

instruction: I feel sad almost every day and I don't enjoy hanging out with my friends anymore. Should I be worried?
output: It is important to pay attention when sadness lasts for a long time and keeps you from enjoying things you usually like. Feeling sad and losing interest in activities (like spending time with friends) are key signs of something called depression, and it is absolutely something to be concerned about and take seriously. It does not mean you are weak or that something is wrong with you—it just means your brain needs some support. The first and most important step is to talk to a trusted adult, like your parents, a counselor, or a school nurse. They can help you find a mental health professional who can guide you on the path to feeling better.

instruction: I have so much homework and my parents are fighting all the time. I feel completely stressed and overwhelmed. What can I do?
output: It sounds like you are carrying a very heavy load right now, and it is completely normal to feel overwhelmed when faced with stress from multiple areas. Let's focus on what you can control. First, create a small, manageable plan for your homework: break it into 20-30 minute chunks with short breaks in between. Second, remember that you are not responsible for your parents' arguments, and you cannot fix their problems. To manage your stress, try setting aside 15 minutes each day for something just for you, like listening to music, coloring, or just lying down quietly. If the stress is constantly too much, please talk to a school counselor about how overwhelmed you feel.

instruction: I feel like I'm not good at anything and I don't have the confidence to try new things. How can I believe in myself?
output: Low confidence is a feeling, not a fact about who you are. To build self-esteem, you need to prove to yourself that you are capable. Start small! Instead of aiming for big, scary goals, pick one very small, new task—like learning a basic skill, completing a small project, or offering to help someone. When you complete it, acknowledge your success! Don't let your inner critic boss you around. When you hear a negative thought, challenge it: 'Is that really true? Or is my fear talking?' Confidence comes from recognizing your small victories and treating yourself with the same kindness you would show a best friend.

instruction: I get so angry that I yell at my family, and then I feel terrible afterwards. How do I stop getting so mad?
output: It is wonderful that you recognize this pattern and want to change it—that takes emotional maturity. The key is to manage the anger before it gets to the yelling stage. Think of anger like a boiling pot; you need to turn the heat down. The next time you start to feel your temper rising (maybe your heart is pounding or your hands clench), use a 'Time-In' strategy. Physically remove yourself from the situation: say, 'I need a minute,' and go to a private space. There, try deep breathing, count backwards from ten, or splash cold water on your face. Once you are calm, you can come back and discuss the issue clearly, without yelling.

instruction: My family is moving to a new city next month, and I'm really sad about leaving my friends. I don't want to start over.
output: It is perfectly normal and valid to feel sad, anxious, and resistant to such a big change. You are not just leaving a place; you are grieving the loss of your daily routine and the easy access to your close friends. Acknowledge the sadness and allow yourself to mourn what you are leaving behind. Then, focus on what you can keep. Plan virtual hangouts with your old friends, and set a goal to make just one new connection in the new city each week. Focus on exploring the new area and finding one thing you can look forward to. Change is hard, but you are resilient and capable of building a happy life in a new place.

instruction: What are some easy things I can do every day to make sure I am taking care of my mental health?
output: Self-care doesn't have to be complicated or expensive! Focus on these simple daily habits: Prioritize Sleep: Get consistent, quality sleep (8-10 hours). Mindful Movement: Spend 30 minutes moving your body, like dancing, walking, or stretching. Nourish Your Body: Eat regular, balanced meals. Connect: Spend some time talking or laughing with someone you care about. Take a Break: Have at least 15 minutes of device-free time to just sit quietly or do a relaxing activity like coloring or listening to music. Small actions done consistently make a huge difference to your emotional well-being over time.

instruction: A girl at school is spreading mean rumors about me online and telling people not to talk to me. What should I do?
output: That is absolutely bullying, and it is unacceptable. You should not have to deal with this alone. First, do not respond or retaliate—it will only make the situation worse. Take screenshots of all the mean messages and posts as evidence. Then, immediately block and report the girl on all platforms. The most critical step is to tell a trusted adult—your parent, a teacher, or the school principal. They have procedures in place to stop bullying, especially cyberbullying, and they can ensure your safety and well-being at school.

instruction: I feel like I don't really have any close friends, and I feel very lonely at lunch. How can I feel less isolated?
output: Feeling lonely is a painful emotion, and it is a sign that your need for connection is not being met. Please know that many people feel this way, even if they look popular. To feel less isolated, focus on a small, achievable action: Join a club or group that matches one of your interests (art, books, sports, etc.). Shared interests are the easiest way to start conversations. At lunch, try sitting next to someone who is sitting alone and start with a simple question about the class you just had or the food. Consistency is key—keep showing up and being open to connection. In the meantime, be a good friend to yourself by practicing self-care and kindness.

instruction: When I try to tell my mom how I feel, I can't find the right words and end up just crying. How can I communicate better?
output: It is frustrating when your emotions block your ability to talk. This is common! The best way to communicate when your feelings are intense is to write it down first. Before you talk to her, write a letter, an email, or even a list of bullet points detailing what you are feeling and what you need. Then, when you approach your mom, you can say, 'Mom, I really need to talk to you, but I'm worried I'll get too emotional. Can I read this to you?' This takes the pressure off finding the words in the moment, lets you organize your thoughts, and gives her a clear understanding of your feelings.

instruction: I am worried about my little sister, she seems very withdrawn and quiet after our house was robbed. What should I do?
output: It is very caring of you to notice her change in behavior. Experiencing a crime, even indirectly, can be traumatic and cause someone to feel insecure or fearful. Withdrawal and quietness can be a sign she is struggling to cope. You can help her by creating a sense of safety and predictability: Encourage her to talk about what she saw or felt, but don't pressure her if she doesn't want to. Maintain her normal routine as much as possible, and encourage her to do activities she usually enjoys. Most importantly, you must tell a trusted adult (your parents, a counselor, or a teacher) so they can seek professional help for her, like child trauma counseling, which is the most effective support.

instruction: How can I become stronger and stop being so sensitive when people criticize me or when things go wrong?
output: The ability to 'bounce back' from difficulties is called resilience, and it is like a muscle you can strengthen! The first step is to change how you talk to yourself: when you face criticism or failure, don't generalize it. Instead of thinking, 'I am a failure,' try, 'This task didn't work out, but I can learn from it.' Second, focus on problem-solving instead of self-blame. Ask yourself, 'What is one small step I can take right now to make this better?' Remember all the times you have faced difficulty and made it through. Acknowledge your strength in those past moments. Being sensitive is okay, but being resilient means letting those feelings pass while you keep moving forward.

instruction: I have really bad cramps every month that make me miss school. Is this normal and what can I do to make the pain stop?
output: Severe cramping (Dysmenorrhea) is very common, but pain that makes you miss school should be addressed seriously. It's not something you just have to endure. For relief, try these things: Over-the-Counter Pain Relievers (like Ibuprofen or Naproxen, taken as directed, starting the day before your period is expected), using a Heating Pad or Hot Water Bottle on your lower abdomen, and Light Exercise (like walking or gentle stretching). If these methods don't help, or if the pain is sudden and severe, you should speak to a healthcare provider (doctor or gynecologist). They can check for underlying issues and may prescribe stronger medication or suggest other treatments. You deserve to be comfortable!

instruction: What is ovulation, and why do I sometimes feel a sharp pain in my side in the middle of the month?
output: Ovulation is a key part of your menstrual cycle. It is when one of your ovaries releases a mature egg. This usually happens about 14 days before your next period is due. The sharp pain you are feeling in the middle of your cycle is likely 'mittelschmerz' (German for 'middle pain'), which is a small, temporary pain or cramp felt by some girls during ovulation as the egg is released. It is usually harmless and can switch sides each month depending on which ovary is working. You can keep track of it to understand your cycle better, and mild over-the-counter pain relief can help if it bothers you.

instruction: Why do my moods change so much now? One minute I'm happy, the next I'm crying about nothing.
output: This rollercoaster of emotions is totally normal and a very common part of puberty! The dramatic mood swings are caused by the big changes happening with your hormones (like estrogen and progesterone). Your brain is also still developing, especially the parts that help control emotions. Try to recognize the feeling when it happens and name it: 'I feel frustrated right now.' Give yourself a healthy outlet for these strong feelings, like listening to music, writing in a journal, or taking a few minutes of quiet time. It can feel chaotic now, but these swings will lessen as your hormones settle down over time.

instruction: Is it okay to swim or take a bath when I have my period? Will it be unsanitary?
output: Yes, it is absolutely okay and perfectly safe to swim or take a bath when you have your period! Water will not affect your cycle, and it is not unsanitary. If you are swimming, you should use a tampon or a menstrual cup to manage your flow, as pads are not effective in water. If you prefer taking a bath, the water pressure usually stops the flow temporarily, and you can simply wash as normal. In fact, warm baths can often help to soothe menstrual cramps!

instruction: What does consent mean when I'm just talking to someone online? Does it still matter?
output: Yes, consent absolutely matters in every interaction, especially online! Online consent means clearly and freely agreeing to how you are being communicated with and what information is being shared. For example, if someone asks for a picture and you say 'No,' they must accept that 'No.' If they ask to video chat, you must agree. If you say, 'I'm not comfortable talking about that,' they need to change the topic. Consent online is about respecting boundaries and privacy, and you have the right to leave any conversation or say 'no' to any request that makes you uncomfortable, at any time.

instruction: How can I tell if a new person I meet is trustworthy and would make a good friend?
output: Trust is something that is earned over time, but you can look for some key indicators early on. A good, trustworthy friend will: Respect your boundaries (they listen when you say 'no'), Be honest (they don't make up stories or gossip), Keep their promises (they show up when they say they will), and Support you (they are happy for your success and there for you when you're sad). Be cautious of people who talk badly about everyone else, try to rush the friendship, or pressure you to do things you don't like. Pay attention to how they treat other people, not just how they treat you.

instruction: Everyone in my class is cheating on a test, and I feel like I have to do it too so my grades don't look bad compared to theirs. What should I do?
output: That is a very tough situation that puts pressure on your moral compass. You are feeling pressure to cheat, but you know it is wrong, and that shows strong character. Remember that cheating is a violation of your own integrity and can have serious consequences if you are caught. Your grades should reflect your own effort and knowledge. The best thing to do is to stick to your values and study honestly. If you are worried about your actual performance, focus your energy on studying smarter or talking to your teacher privately for extra help. Your honest effort is always more valuable than a dishonest high grade.

instruction: I got acne recently and it makes me want to hide my face. I feel really ugly. How can I handle this change?
output: Acne is an incredibly common part of puberty, and many girls feel exactly the way you do—it can really affect your confidence. Please be kind to yourself. Acne is temporary, but the skin underneath is still yours. To manage it, keep a simple skincare routine: wash your face twice a day with a gentle cleanser, and avoid picking at the spots, which can make them worse. Most importantly, remember that acne does not define your beauty or your worth. People see your smile, your eyes, and your personality, not just a few spots. If your acne is severe, ask a parent to take you to a dermatologist (skin doctor) for professional advice.

instruction: My mom told me not to accept rides from strangers, but what if they look like a nice person? How do I know for sure?
output: This is a great question, because a dangerous person doesn't always 'look' dangerous. The rule is simple and absolute: Never accept a ride from someone you don't know and trust completely, regardless of how 'nice' they look. Safety rules are for everyone, and a trusted adult will respect the rule and understand why you must say no. If a stranger approaches you and offers a ride, decline politely but firmly, and immediately walk towards a busy public place or a trusted person like a store clerk or a police officer. When in doubt, always default to the safety rule.

instruction: A coach I really like keeps asking me to keep secrets about things we do at practice. Is this a bad sign?
output: Yes, that is a huge red flag and a concerning sign. When an adult in a position of power, like a coach, asks a young person to keep secrets, it is a tactic used to isolate and manipulate. Healthy, safe adult-child relationships do not require secrets. Your coach should be trustworthy and transparent. You are not obligated to keep a secret that makes you uncomfortable, confused, or scared. You need to tell a trusted adult immediately—a parent, the principal, or another teacher. This is a serious situation that needs adult intervention to ensure your safety and the safety of any other girls on the team.

instruction: My friend always borrows my clothes and doesn't return them or returns them dirty. I don't want to lend her things anymore. How do I say no without being mean?
output: It is completely fair to set a boundary when someone repeatedly disrespects your property. Saying 'no' is not mean—it is necessary for self-respect. You can say something kind but firm, like: 'I'm sorry, but I actually can't lend out my clothes anymore.' If she presses you, you can simply repeat: 'I know, and I really wish I could, but I've decided I'm not lending out my things right now.' You don't need a detailed explanation or excuse. Just be calm, firm, and consistent. A good friend will respect your decision.

instruction: What if the person who is making me feel bad is my own parent? Who can I ask for help then?
output: That is a very difficult and painful position to be in, and you absolutely deserve help. If you cannot turn to one parent, the best thing to do is reach out to another close, trusted relative (like an aunt, uncle, or older sibling) and explain the situation to them. If that's not possible, your school counselor, school nurse, or a specific teacher can also help. They are mandatory reporters, meaning they are required by law to take action to protect you. You can also call a child help line, where trained professionals can guide you on what to do next. Remember, your safety and well-being are a priority.

instruction: Someone I just met online is asking me to send a 'fun photo' of myself. Should I do it?
output: No, you should absolutely NOT send any photo or video of yourself, especially one that could be considered private or 'fun' in a suggestive way. This is a common tactic called 'sextortion' or grooming. Once an image is sent, you lose all control over it forever, and it can be copied, shared, or used to blackmail you. Remember that people online are not always who they say they are. Immediately stop the conversation, block the person, and report the message to the platform. If you have any concerns, talk to a trusted adult right away.

instruction: A website asked for my mom's credit card number to verify my age. Is this safe?
output: No, this is highly suspicious and very likely not safe. A legitimate website will never ask for a parent's credit card number just to verify your age, and giving out financial information online can lead to serious problems like identity theft or unauthorized charges. Never share credit card numbers, bank details, or Social Security numbers. If a website asks for this, immediately close the page and tell your mother about it so she can check the site's legitimacy and ensure her information is protected.

instruction: There is a classmate who keeps trying to follow me on Instagram after I blocked him. What can I do about this unwanted attention?
output: This behavior is persistent and inappropriate, and you have every right to stop it. Since you've already blocked him, here are the next steps: 1. Document Everything: Take screenshots of the follow requests and any messages. 2. Review Privacy: Double-check that all your social media accounts are set to the highest privacy settings. 3. Tell an Adult: Inform a trusted school staff member (teacher, counselor, or administrator) about his persistent and unwanted attention. This is a school issue, and they need to intervene by speaking to him and his parents. Your safety and peace of mind online and at school matter.

instruction: I'm looking for a place to volunteer to feel more connected to my community. How can I find a safe organization to help with?
output: That is a wonderful idea for building connection and confidence! When looking for safe, reliable organizations, look for places that: Have a clear mission (like a reputable food bank, animal shelter, or community library). Require background checks for all adult staff and volunteers. Require adult supervision for all youth volunteers, especially in groups. Check with your school counselor or a religious leader, as they often have lists of established, vetted, and safe community partners where students can volunteer. Always check their website and confirm supervision details with a parent.

instruction: I get so nervous before tests that my mind goes completely blank. I study hard, but I panic. How can I manage test anxiety?
output: Test anxiety is extremely common, especially when you are a dedicated student! Your mind 'blanks' because the stress hormones block access to the memory you actually have. To manage this: Before the Test: Practice deep, slow breathing for 10 minutes. Remind yourself, 'I have studied, and I know this material.' During the Test: If you panic, take a 30-second break, close your eyes, and take three very deep, cleansing breaths. Read the instructions carefully, and start with the easiest questions first—this builds confidence and helps calm your mind. Remember, your score does not define your worth or intelligence.

instruction: I have no energy to do anything, even simple things like getting out of bed feel impossible. Is this part of feeling sad?
output: Yes, a severe lack of energy or feeling physically heavy and drained (often called 'fatigue' or 'lethargy') is a very common and serious symptom of depression. It is not about being lazy; it is a physical manifestation of emotional distress. When your body and mind are fighting a constant battle with sadness, it uses up all your energy stores. This is a significant sign that you need support. Please talk to a trusted adult right away—a parent, school counselor, or doctor—so they can help you feel better and get your energy back.

instruction: How do I decide what to do first when I have a million things to do for school and feel like I'm drowning in tasks?
output: When you feel like you are drowning, the best thing to do is to create a 'triage' plan—a way to manage the immediate stress. Take 15 minutes to make a list of absolutely everything you need to do. Then, divide the list into three categories: Urgent (due today/tomorrow), Important (must be done this week), and Later (can wait). Start with the most urgent task, and only focus on that one thing until it is done. Seeing a small completed task will reduce your stress and give you the motivation to move on to the next one.

instruction: I tend to give up right away when something is hard because I think I'll fail. How can I stop sabotaging myself?
output: That immediate desire to quit is often a fear of failure in disguise. To overcome this, you need to change your mindset from 'I might fail' to 'I am learning.' When you start something difficult, focus on the process, not just the final result. Break the task into tiny, easy steps, and celebrate completing each step. If you make a mistake, reframe it not as a failure, but as feedback—it's information telling you what to try differently next time. Self-confidence grows from seeing yourself keep trying, even when it's hard, not from achieving perfection.

instruction: I cry very easily when I get frustrated or sad, and I hate that I can't control it. What should I do when the tears start?
output: Crying is a healthy way your body releases strong emotion, and there's nothing wrong with being sensitive! However, if you want to manage the timing, when you feel the tears starting, try to mentally redirect the energy. One method is to change your physical state: Get up and walk around, stretch your arms over your head, or take a quick, large sip of cold water. Focus your eyes on one fixed, small point on the wall. These actions engage your physical self and can often interrupt the emotional wave enough to postpone the tears until you are in a private place where you feel safe to let them out.

instruction: My best friend is moving far away, and I feel like my life is falling apart. How do I cope with losing my friend?
output: Losing a best friend to a move feels like a major loss, and your feelings are completely valid. It is a form of grief. Allow yourself time to feel sad. To cope, focus on making the transition easier: Plan a special farewell activity to make happy memories. Create a consistent communication plan (e.g., 'We will video chat every Saturday'). Then, give yourself permission to gradually re-invest in your local life—this doesn't mean replacing her, but creating new connections and activities. You will always be friends, even with distance, and you will grow to make new, wonderful connections where you are.

instruction: What is a 'digital detox' and why should I take a break from my phone sometimes?
output: A 'digital detox' simply means intentionally stepping away from your phone, social media, and other screens for a set period of time (an hour, an afternoon, or even a full day). It is a vital self-care practice because being constantly connected can lead to stress, anxiety, comparison, and poor sleep. Taking a break helps your brain rest, reduces the pressure to compare yourself to others, improves focus, and encourages you to connect with the real world and people around you. Try leaving your phone in another room during mealtimes or the hour before bed.

instruction: I saw someone getting bullied in the hallway, but I was scared to step in. What is the safest way to help someone being bullied?
output: It is completely understandable that you were scared—it takes courage to step in. The safest and most effective way to help a target of bullying is to get help from an adult immediately. This is called 'reporting' or 'getting an intervention.' Go straight to a teacher, a school staff member, or a counselor and tell them exactly what you saw. You should also check on the person being bullied afterwards by saying, 'Are you okay? I saw what happened, and I reported it.' You were not a bystander; you were a witness who needs to speak up to an adult.

instruction: I feel like I don't know how to start conversations with people I want to be friends with. I'm afraid they will think I'm weird.
output: It takes bravery to start a conversation, and the fear of being judged is very common. The key is to ask an open-ended question that gives the other person a chance to talk. You can try: A compliment: 'That shirt is so cool, where did you get it?' A shared experience: 'What did you think of the homework the teacher gave us?' An observation: 'I see you reading that book, is it good?' Keep the conversation light and friendly, and practice deep listening. People usually love talking about themselves, and the more you practice, the easier and more natural it will become.

instruction: When I talk, I only say what I think people want to hear. How can I practice saying what I actually think or feel?
output: This is a great skill to develop, and it starts with using 'I' statements. Instead of trying to guess what others want to hear, focus on your own experience. For example, instead of saying, 'We should all go to the movies,' you can say, 'I would really love to go to the movies.' When you are sharing a feeling, use the format: 'I feel [emotion] when [situation] because [reason].' For example, 'I feel frustrated when I am interrupted because I lose my train of thought.' This communicates your feeling clearly without accusing or blaming anyone else, making it easier for others to listen and respect your actual thoughts.

instruction: I have nightmares almost every night since a difficult family event, and I wake up sweaty and anxious. How can I make them stop?
output: Nightmares following a difficult or traumatic event are a very common way your brain tries to process the stress, but they are exhausting. A simple technique to try is Imagery Rehearsal Therapy (IRT). Before bed, write down the ending of the nightmare and change it into a safe, positive, and calming ending. Then, rehearse the new, better ending in your mind for 5-10 minutes. This helps 're-program' your brain's memory during sleep. You should also talk to a trusted adult and consider seeing a trauma-informed therapist, as they can provide professional tools to help your mind heal and rest.

instruction: What are the small steps I can take to be more resilient and handle life's problems better?
output: Building resilience is about small, consistent efforts. Start by working on three things: 1. Build Connections: Invest time in healthy relationships; having a strong support network is the #1 protector against stress. 2. Adopt Realistic Optimism: Instead of thinking 'everything is ruined,' ask 'What is the most helpful thing I can do right now?' Focus on a tiny, positive step. 3. Practice Self-Compassion: When you mess up or feel pain, talk to yourself the way you would talk to a friend—with kindness and encouragement. Resilience is not about being tough; it's about being flexible and kind to yourself when things get hard.

instruction: I'm worried about the weight gain that is happening during puberty. I don't like my new body shape. Is it possible to stop it?
output: It is very common for girls to experience weight and body shape changes during puberty, and it is a completely normal, healthy, and necessary part of your development. You cannot and should not try to stop these changes—your body is getting stronger and preparing to be an adult body. Instead of focusing on weight, focus on healthy behaviors: eating balanced meals that fuel your body and finding physical activities you genuinely enjoy (like dancing or team sports). Work on accepting that your body is growing and changing. If you have concerns about your eating habits or weight, please talk to a trusted adult or a doctor for guidance, not for trying to stop a healthy, natural process.

instruction: When should I start using tampons, and is it hard to put one in?
output: You can start using tampons any time you feel comfortable and if you want to be more active (like swimming or playing sports) while on your period. There is no 'right' age. It is normal for it to feel difficult or strange the first few times, but it is not physically hard. Read the instructions carefully, use the applicator style, and try to relax your muscles. Use a lower absorbency tampon (like 'slim' or 'light'). If it hurts, it is likely not far enough in. If you are still struggling after a few tries, you can ask a parent or trusted adult for help, or wait and try again another month. Use whatever product makes you feel most comfortable!

instruction: Sometimes I get a lot of white discharge in my underwear. Is this normal or a sign of an infection?
output: It's completely normal to have some vaginal discharge, and it's actually a healthy sign that your reproductive system is cleaning itself! This discharge is usually clear, white, or slightly sticky. The amount and consistency can change throughout your monthly cycle. You should only be worried if the discharge changes dramatically—for example, if it becomes very thick, green or yellow, has a strong fishy odor, or causes itching, burning, or pain. If you notice any of those changes, you should talk to a trusted adult or doctor, as it could be a sign of an infection that needs simple treatment.

instruction: I have to change my pad more than five times a day, and I bleed through clothes sometimes. Is my period too heavy?
output: A period that requires you to change a pad or tampon more than every two hours, or that causes you to bleed through your clothes often, is generally considered a heavy period (also called menorrhagia). While some women naturally have heavier flows, a period this heavy can lead to fatigue and anemia (low iron). You should definitely tell your parent and talk to a doctor. They can check your iron levels and discuss medical options, like certain birth control pills or other treatments, that can help make your flow lighter and more manageable so you don't have to worry about missing school or bleeding through clothes.

instruction: Why do some girls develop much earlier or later than me? I feel out of place.
output: Puberty is a natural, healthy process, but it follows its own unique timeline for everyone—there is no single 'right' age to start. Genetics (the genes you get from your family) play a huge role, so if your mother or female relatives started earlier or later, you might, too. It can feel awkward to be the first or the last in your group, but try to remember that your body is simply developing on its own perfect schedule. Everyone will catch up eventually, and your worth is never tied to how fast or slow your body changes.

instruction: What should I do if I get my period unexpectedly while I'm at school and I don't have a pad?
output: Don't panic! This happens to almost every girl at some point. The first thing you should do is calmly go to a trusted female teacher, the school nurse, or the front office. They almost always have emergency supplies. If you cannot find a pad right away, you can use a few layers of toilet paper wrapped around your underwear as a temporary measure until you can get a proper pad. Remember, this is a normal body process, and school staff are trained to help you with this discreetly.

instruction: If a boy keeps trying to hold my hand and I pull it away, is that enough to count as saying 'no'?
output: Yes, absolutely! Pulling your hand away is a clear, non-verbal way of communicating 'no' and setting a physical boundary. Consent isn't just about saying the word; it's about freely and enthusiastically agreeing. If a person continues to try to hold your hand after you've pulled away, they are ignoring your boundary, which is disrespectful and wrong. If they persist, you must use your voice and clearly say, 'Please stop, I do not want you to hold my hand.'

instruction: My friend gets really jealous when I hang out with other people. How do I handle her jealousy without making her angry?
output: It is difficult when a friend's feelings cause you stress. While you can be kind, you are not responsible for managing her emotions. A healthy relationship allows both people to have other friends and interests. You can address the behavior calmly by using an 'I' statement: 'I value our friendship, and I also need time to hang out with other friends. I want to spend time with you too, maybe we can plan something on Friday?' If she gets angry or tries to isolate you, it's a sign the friendship is becoming unhealthy, and you may need to create some distance.

instruction: My friends are all making fun of another girl in our class, and I don't think it's funny. If I don't laugh, will they start making fun of me?
output: This is a form of peer pressure called 'bystander pressure,' and it takes great moral courage to stand against it. You don't have to join in or laugh to be their friend. The simplest, safest way to handle it is to remain silent, look away, or change the subject immediately. You can say something quiet like, 'I'm actually not interested in this topic, let's talk about the movie instead.' If they pressure you, remember: True friends won't make you sacrifice your conscience or your kindness. By not joining in, you are quietly showing strength and integrity.

instruction: Everyone online talks about being thin and curvy at the same time. I don't fit that look. What is the 'right' body type?
output: There is no single 'right' body type, and the images you see online are often unrealistic, digitally altered, and constantly changing to sell products. The 'right' body type is simply the one you have! Every body is unique, and all bodies come in different beautiful shapes, sizes, and curves. Focus on being a healthy, strong, and active version of yourself, not on trying to fit into a trend or an image. Remember that your character, kindness, and intelligence are far more important than your measurements.

instruction: What should I do if I get lost in a large, crowded place like a market or fair?
output: If you realize you are lost, do not wander around looking for your group. Find a safe spot and stay there. The safe spot should be near a trusted authority figure: A police officer, a security guard, a store clerk, or a family with children. Tell them calmly, 'I am lost and I need help finding my parent/guardian.' Be ready to give them your name, your parent's name, and their phone number. If you cannot find an authority figure, go to the nearest store or stand and ask a staff member for help to call your family. Never go off with someone you do not know.

instruction: I have an uncle who makes jokes that make me feel uncomfortable, but everyone else laughs. How do I know if the jokes are inappropriate?
output: Your feelings are the most important indicator. If a joke or comment makes you feel uncomfortable, confused, 'icky,' ashamed, or tense, then for you, it is inappropriate. It doesn't matter if others are laughing. Inappropriate behavior from an adult often targets your privacy, your body, or involves sexual or demeaning comments. You have the right to leave the room or simply not laugh. If the jokes are about you, or if they continue to make you uncomfortable, you must tell a trusted, non-involved adult (like your other parent or a school counselor) what is happening and how it makes you feel.

instruction: My teacher gave me a lot of extra work, and I'm already overwhelmed. How can I respectfully say 'no' to an adult?
output: It takes courage to set a boundary with an adult, but it is important to protect your time and energy. You can say 'no' respectfully by being honest and brief. Try this: 'Thank you for thinking of me, but I actually have a lot on my plate this week, and I'm worried I can't give this new task the attention it deserves.' If you are worried about your current workload, you could say, 'I'm feeling very overwhelmed with my current assignments; could we prioritize which ones are most important right now?' This communicates your limit without being disrespectful.

instruction: My friend's parent got angry when I told them I didn't want to go to their house. How do I know if an adult is untrustworthy?
output: That adult's reaction—getting angry when you set a simple boundary—is a very strong sign that they might not be trustworthy. A trustworthy adult will always respect your 'no.' Signs an adult might be untrustworthy include: Getting upset or angry when you set a boundary (like saying 'no'), Asking you to keep secrets from your parents or other trusted adults, Drinking or using drugs excessively, or Treating you, or others, with disrespect or meanness. Always listen to your gut feeling; if you feel tense or uneasy around an adult, it is better to trust your instincts and keep your distance.

instruction: Someone I know online started sending me inappropriate messages. What do I do immediately?
output: This is called cyber-flirting or harassment, and you need to stop it immediately. 1. Do not respond. Any response (even telling them to stop) can encourage them. 2. Take screenshots of the messages as evidence. 3. Block and report the person immediately on the platform they are using. 4. Tell a trusted adult. This is not your fault, and a trusted adult needs to know so they can help you ensure your safety and report the activity to the police if necessary. Deleting the messages is not enough; you must save the evidence and report it.

instruction: Is it safe to share my phone number with people on the bus or at a community event if they ask?
output: It is best to be very cautious about sharing your phone number, especially with people you have just met. Your phone number can be used to track you, harass you, or share other private information about you. If someone asks for your number and you are interested in a friendship, you can suggest a safer alternative, like connecting on a private social media profile you control or suggesting you exchange a message through a trusted friend first. Never feel pressured to give out your contact information, as it is a key piece of personal data.

instruction: How do I deal with people shouting comments at me (catcalling) when I walk outside?
output: Dealing with catcalling or verbal street harassment is frustrating, upsetting, and inappropriate. The best and safest thing you can do is do not engage. Do not make eye contact, do not stop walking, and do not respond. Walk with purpose and confidence, and head straight to a public, safe area. If it happens frequently on a certain route, change your route or walk with a friend. Your safety is more important than confrontation, and their behavior is a reflection of them, not you.

instruction: Besides my school and home, what are common examples of safe spaces in my town?
output: A safe space is any public place where you feel protected and can go to if you are in danger or need help. Good examples of safe spaces in a community include: Local libraries, Police or fire stations, Established, large religious institutions (like a church, mosque, or temple), Reputable, busy businesses with staff present (like a bank or a major grocery store), and sometimes, a Trusted neighbor's house where the adults know your family and you feel comfortable. Look for places that are well-lit and have visible staff members.

instruction: I feel like I have to be perfect at everything I do, and if I make one mistake, I cry. How do I stop being a perfectionist?
output: Perfectionism is often an anxiety-driven fear of failure, and it can be exhausting. To reduce this pressure, try setting a new goal: Aim for 'Good Enough' instead of 'Perfect.' This means accepting a grade of 'B' or 'C' on a task that would have taken you ten hours to make 'A' perfect. When you make a mistake, practice self-compassion by saying, 'I made a mistake, that's okay, I'm learning.' Acknowledge that the biggest success is completing the task, not doing it without error. This will slowly reduce the intensity of your performance anxiety.

instruction: Sometimes I feel completely numb and empty, like I can't feel happy or sad. What does this 'emptiness' mean?
output: That feeling of being 'numb' or 'empty' is called emotional blunting, and it is a common symptom of depression or severe stress. When your emotions are too overwhelming, your mind sometimes shuts down to protect itself. This state of emptiness means you are emotionally exhausted. It is a serious sign that you need to seek professional mental health support. Please tell a trusted adult about this feeling right away. You deserve to feel the full range of human emotions, and a counselor can help you reconnect with your feelings in a safe way.

instruction: My parents expect me to be the best student, and I feel immense pressure to get straight A's. I'm scared to disappoint them.
output: The pressure to meet high parental expectations can be an incredible source of stress. First, remember that your worth is not tied to your grades. To manage the pressure, you need to gently communicate your feelings to your parents. You could say, 'I know you want me to do well, but I am feeling very overwhelmed by the pressure to get straight A's. This level of stress is making me feel burnt out.' See if you can negotiate a sustainable standard, like 'doing your best' or aiming for a slightly lower, achievable grade. If they don't listen, talk to your school counselor about how to manage the stress from home.

instruction: I failed a test really badly, and now I feel worthless and want to give up on the subject. How can I feel better about this failure?
output: A bad grade can feel devastating, but it is one moment in time—it does not define your future or your self-worth. It is important to separate your actions from your identity: 'I got a bad grade' is a fact; 'I am a failure' is a harmful lie. To move on, first, take a deep breath and accept the feeling of disappointment. Second, ask yourself, 'What is one concrete thing I can learn from this setback?' (e.g., I need to study earlier, or I need to ask the teacher for help). Focus on taking that one positive step forward. Your ability to learn and try again is what builds your strength and self-esteem.

instruction: I spend money impulsively, and I sometimes eat too much junk food when I'm stressed. How can I control these impulses?
output: Impulsive behaviors are often a way your brain tries to cope with strong or unpleasant emotions. The key to controlling the impulse is to create a 'pause' between the trigger (the stress/emotion) and the action (the spending/eating). When you feel the urge, use the 'Ride the Wave' technique: Acknowledge the feeling (e.g., 'I feel stressed and want to eat junk food'), remind yourself that the urge is temporary, and then do a distraction activity for 15 minutes (call a friend, do a chore, listen to music). The urge will usually lessen after the peak, allowing you to choose a healthier response.

instruction: I got a new teacher this year, and I miss my old one who I felt very close to. I feel anxious about starting over.
output: It is completely understandable to feel a sense of loss and anxiety when you lose a trusted, close relationship, even if it is a teacher. This is a common way to cope with change. Acknowledge the sadness you feel about the change. Then, focus on finding one small positive thing about the new teacher or class. Instead of expecting the new teacher to be the same, focus on building a new, healthy connection with them by simply participating and being open. Remember that the positive relationships you build at school are a testament to your ability to connect with others, and you can do it again.

instruction: Is it okay to sometimes say 'no' to my friends' invitations and just stay home alone? I feel guilty if I do.
output: Yes, absolutely! Saying 'no' to social invitations and choosing to stay home is a vital part of self-care. It means you are listening to your body's need for rest, solitude, and quiet time. You need to recharge your energy, especially if you're an introvert or have a busy week. You can decline gently by saying, 'Thank you so much for the invite, but I need a quiet night to recharge. I'll see you on [next day].' Never feel guilty for prioritizing your own mental and physical well-being. Good friends will understand.

instruction: My friends are not directly mean, but they always exclude me from things and talk about secrets when I'm around. Is this still bullying?
output: Yes, this behavior is absolutely a form of relational bullying or social aggression. Bullying is not always physical; exclusion, gossiping, and purposely making someone feel left out or isolated is a deeply hurtful and unacceptable way to treat a friend. This creates an unhealthy and toxic dynamic. You need to tell a trusted adult what is happening. While you do that, focus on distancing yourself from people who actively exclude you and investing your time in kinder, more supportive people who make you feel respected.

instruction: I'm surrounded by people at school and at home, but I still feel disconnected and lonely. Why do I feel this way?
output: That feeling of being lonely in a crowd is very common and can be painful. It often happens when the connections you have are not deeply meaningful or authentic. You might be feeling disconnected because you are holding back your true self, or the people around you are not truly listening and engaging with you. To combat this, try focusing on quality over quantity. Find one person you feel safe with and have one honest, deep conversation about something that truly matters to you. Sharing your real self is the key to creating a true connection and reducing that isolated feeling.

instruction: I feel afraid to ask my parents for emotional support because they always try to fix my problems instead of just listening.
output: It is frustrating when you just need to be heard and you get advice instead. Your parents are likely trying to help, but they are missing the difference between 'listening' and 'fixing.' To get the support you need, you must tell them exactly what you need before you start talking. Try using a clear opener like: 'Mom/Dad, I need to talk about something that is really bothering me. I don't need you to solve it; I just need you to listen right now. Can you please just listen until I'm done talking?' This sets a boundary and tells them how to communicate with you effectively.

instruction: I keep having intrusive, scary thoughts that flash into my mind, and I can't stop them. Are these normal after a trauma?
output: Yes, having intrusive thoughts, images, or 'flashbacks' is a very common reaction after a traumatic or highly stressful event. Your brain is essentially trying to process and file away the memory, and it hasn't quite succeeded. These thoughts are just thoughts—they are not reality, and they cannot harm you. When they happen, remind yourself: 'This is just a memory/thought, and it will pass.' You must talk to a trusted adult and seek counseling from a therapist who specializes in trauma, as they can teach you effective techniques to help your brain process and calm these thoughts.

instruction: Why do I feel so much pressure to always be happy and positive, and what should I do when I feel a negative emotion?
output: There is a strong cultural pressure to always seem happy, especially on social media, but no one is truly happy all the time. It is vital to remember that all emotions—sadness, anger, frustration, and worry—are normal, healthy parts of being human. They are messages from your body. When you feel a negative emotion, don't try to instantly fight it or make it disappear. Instead, acknowledge it without judgment: say to yourself, 'I feel frustrated right now, and that's okay.' Then, allow yourself to feel it for a few minutes before choosing a healthy action (like deep breathing, journaling, or talking to a friend).

instruction: How is it possible to be friends with someone without gossiping about other people?
output: It is absolutely possible, and it’s a sign of a high-quality, healthy friendship. Friends who rely on gossiping or criticizing others to connect are often insecure themselves. To build a friendship without gossip, focus on shared experiences, deep listening, and talking about ideas instead of people. Ask your friend genuine, open-ended questions about their life, interests, or feelings. If a friend starts to gossip, gently change the topic: 'Oh, before we talk about that, what did you think of the new movie?' or 'I'd rather not talk about her; let's talk about the concert instead.'

instruction: Is the idea of 'stranger danger' really what I should be worried about for safety?
output: While 'stranger danger' is a good starting point for general caution, the real danger is often not the 'scary stranger' but people you know and trust. Most abusive situations or safety violations against young people are committed by someone the child knows—a family member, family friend, or someone in a position of trust (like a coach or a teacher). The best rule to teach yourself is 'Tricky People/Unsafe Situations': A 'tricky person' is anyone who asks you to break a family rule, keep a secret, or makes you feel uncomfortable, regardless of whether you know them or not. Focus on listening to your gut feeling about a person's behavior, not just if they are a stranger.

instruction: I have terrible mood swings a few days before my period. I get really angry and sad. Is there a name for this and how do I deal with it?
output: The mood swings you are describing before your period have a name: Premenstrual Syndrome (PMS). It's caused by the natural drop in your hormones (estrogen and progesterone) right before your period starts. To deal with it, try to keep a journal to track when it happens—awareness is the first step. During those days, focus on: Extra rest, Reducing caffeine and sugar, and Gentle exercise (like walking). Most importantly, give yourself permission to feel your emotions without judgment and let your trusted adults know when this phase is happening so they can be more supportive and understanding.

instruction: What is the purpose of having a period if I'm not planning to have a baby right now?
output: That's a very practical question! The primary purpose of the menstrual cycle is to prepare the body for a potential pregnancy, but even if you don't plan to have a baby, the cycle is still incredibly important for your overall health. Your period is a sign of a healthy, functioning endocrine system (hormones). The cycle, specifically the hormones estrogen and progesterone, are essential for building strong bones, keeping your heart healthy, and maintaining brain health throughout your life. Think of it as a monthly check-up that shows your body is healthy and functioning properly!

instruction: My voice is starting to change and get a little deeper, and I feel embarrassed. Do girls' voices change like boys' voices do?
output: Yes, girls' voices change during puberty too, but it's often more subtle than the deep 'breaking' voice change that boys experience. Your vocal cords grow longer and thicker because of the increase in hormones, which naturally lowers the pitch of your voice. This can happen gradually, sometimes resulting in a slightly deeper or fuller tone. It's nothing to be embarrassed about—it is just another sign your body is maturing and becoming an adult. This change is completely normal and won't be as dramatic as you might think!

instruction: Sometimes I forget to change my pad all day because I'm busy. What are the risks of leaving a pad on for too long?
output: It is important to be consistent with changing your sanitary products. Leaving a pad on for too long (more than 4-6 hours) can create a warm, moist environment that encourages the growth of bacteria. This can lead to: Unpleasant odors, Skin irritation and rashes in the sensitive area, and Increased risk of infection (like a yeast infection). Set a discreet reminder on your phone or watch for every 3-4 hours to ensure you change your pad regularly. It's a small, easy habit that makes a huge difference to your hygiene and comfort.

instruction: What is the difference between an honest mistake and someone deliberately doing something hurtful?
output: That distinction is based on intent and consequence. An honest mistake is when someone does something that causes harm or discomfort, but they didn't mean to, and they show remorse when they realize the impact. They apologize sincerely and change their behavior. A deliberate hurtful action is when someone intends to cause distress, or they continue the action even after you've told them it is causing harm. If someone continues to ignore your 'no' or your feelings, it is a deliberate, hurtful action, and you should not accept it or excuse it.

instruction: How can I get out of a toxic friendship without starting a huge fight or drama?
output: The most effective way to end a toxic friendship is often through a process called 'fading away' or 'slow distancing.' You don't need a confrontational talk, which the drama-seeking friend might try to turn into a fight. Instead: Respond less quickly and less often to their messages. Be less available to hang out by saying you are busy. Keep your conversations brief and neutral. Over time, they will likely get the hint and find other people to engage with. If they demand a reason, you can keep it simple: 'I'm focusing on my studies/myself right now,' without placing blame.

instruction: My friends are encouraging me to ditch school and say 'it's just one day.' I'm worried about getting in trouble. How can I stand firm and say no?
output: You are right to be worried—skipping school can lead to serious consequences and is not worth the risk. Your concern about getting in trouble shows you have good judgment. To stand firm, be direct and unapologetic. You can say: 'No, I can't. I'm not going to risk getting in trouble with my parents or the school.' Or simply: 'Thanks, but I'm going to class.' True friends respect your decisions, especially when you are protecting yourself from getting into trouble. Stick to your choice, and walk confidently toward your class.

instruction: I feel pressured to wear makeup because all the other girls at school do. I don't like how it feels. What should I do?
output: You should only wear makeup if you want to, not because you feel pressured by others. Makeup is a choice, not a requirement for being beautiful, popular, or accepted. If you don't like how it feels, don't wear it! Your natural face is wonderful. You can politely shut down the peer pressure by saying, 'I'm happy with how I look without it,' or 'I'm just not into makeup right now.' Confidence comes from within, not from what you put on your face. Embrace your natural self, and you will find that true friends admire your confidence and authenticity.

instruction: My school is close to a main road. What are the best ways to ensure safety when crossing the street and walking home?
output: When walking near traffic, always prioritize visibility and awareness. Put your phone away and take off your headphones so you can hear traffic and surrounding noises. Cross at designated crossings (traffic lights or crosswalks) whenever possible. Make eye contact with drivers to ensure they see you before you step off the curb. And remember the golden rule: Always look left, right, and left again before crossing. If a road is very busy, consider walking with a friend or asking a parent if there is a safer, less busy route you can take.

instruction: My younger sibling is being touched by a relative in a way that makes me uneasy, but they say it's normal. How do I know if it's wrong?
output: Your protective instinct and uneasy feeling are your best guide, and you must trust them. If any touch or behavior makes you feel uneasy, it's a sign that it is wrong. A safe, healthy touch is openly done, makes you feel comfortable, and is appropriate for the situation (like a hug on greeting). Inappropriate behavior often involves: Secrecy ('Don't tell anyone'), Touching private body parts, Making you feel confused or ashamed, or Disregarding your feelings. You need to tell a trusted, non-involved adult (parent, teacher, counselor, or another relative) about this immediately. This is not something you should keep secret.

instruction: I lent money to a friend a long time ago, and she never brought it up. How do I ask for it back without damaging our friendship?
output: It's awkward to ask for money, but you have the right to get back what you lent. You can approach it in a friendly, casual way to make it less tense. Try saying something like: 'Hey, I'm just organizing my spending for the month, and I was wondering when you might be able to pay back the [amount] I lent you a while back?' Or, if she mentions something she is buying: 'Oh, that's great! When you get a chance, could you pay me back for that money I lent you a few weeks ago? I could really use it for [reason].' If she is a true friend, she will understand and pay you back.

instruction: What if my parent is the one that's abusing alcohol and that makes me feel unsafe at home? Who should I talk to?
output: That is a very scary and difficult situation, and you must prioritize your own safety and well-being. The best person to talk to is your school counselor or a school administrator. They are professionals who understand difficult family dynamics and have resources to help you, without you having to handle the situation alone. You can also call a local or national child help line, where trained counselors can offer immediate, confidential support and guidance on what steps to take next. You are not responsible for your parent's actions, but you are responsible for keeping yourself safe.

instruction: I keep getting sent links to websites from people I barely know. Is it safe to click on them?
output: No, it is generally very unsafe to click on links sent to you by people you don't know well or completely trust. These links can lead to: Viruses or malware that steal information from your phone or computer, Inappropriate or upsetting content, or Phishing scams that try to trick you into sharing passwords or personal information. The best rule is: If you don't know the person or trust the source, do not click the link. Immediately delete the message and block the sender.

instruction: I posted a photo of my school uniform online. Is that a privacy risk?
output: Yes, it can be a privacy risk. Even though a uniform is just clothing, posting a photo of yourself in it—especially if you mention your school's name or show a recognizable emblem—gives away information that someone could use to locate you. You should be cautious about sharing details that narrow down your location. In the future, it's best to avoid posting photos that clearly show your school uniform, your house, or the street you live on. If you are worried about the photo you already posted, you can remove it or crop out the uniform emblem.

instruction: A peer keeps sending me texts that criticize my clothes and hair. This is making me feel awful. How do I stop it?
output: This is a form of cyber-harassment, and you need to take action to stop it. 1. Do not engage or respond. Do not give them the attention they are looking for. 2. Block their number immediately so they cannot text you anymore. 3. Take a screenshot of the texts as evidence. 4. Show the evidence to a trusted adult (parent or school staff) and explain that a peer is harassing you. The school can then intervene with the student, and your adult can help you stay protected. You do not have to put up with unkindness.

instruction: What makes a person a 'safe person' to be around?
output: A safe person is someone who makes you feel respected, heard, and protected. Look for these qualities: They listen to you without judgment. They respect your boundaries (they accept your 'no'). They follow through on their promises. They treat everyone with respect (not just you). They have a good, healthy relationship with their own emotions. And most importantly, You feel calm and comfortable when you are around them. Trust your intuition—if a person makes you feel uneasy, they are not a safe person for you.

instruction: I am worried about something, and the more I try not to think about it, the more I worry. How can I control my worrying thoughts?
output: Trying to stop a worry often makes it worse! Instead, try a technique called 'Worry Time.' This gives your worry a specific, contained place and time, so it doesn't take over your whole day. 1. Designate a 15-minute 'Worry Time' each day (e.g., 5 PM). 2. When a worry pops up earlier in the day, write it down quickly on a small piece of paper or in a 'worry log.' 3. Tell yourself: 'I will think about this later during my Worry Time.' 4. When Worry Time comes, review your list. You will find that many worries no longer seem important. For the ones that still matter, you can focus on making a small action plan to address them. This puts you in control of the worry.

instruction: I just don't feel motivated to do anything, and I always feel tired. Is this just laziness or something more serious?
output: It is very unlikely to be 'laziness.' A persistent lack of motivation and constant fatigue are significant symptoms that your body and mind are struggling. When you feel this way, it often indicates a low mood, depression, or emotional exhaustion, which are real medical conditions. It's vital that you do not blame yourself. The first step is to share this feeling of persistent tiredness and lack of motivation with a trusted adult and ask to see a doctor or mental health professional. You may need support to regain your energy and motivation, and that is a sign of strength, not weakness.

instruction: When I am stressed, I sometimes scratch my skin or pick at my nails without realizing it. How can I stop these nervous habits?
output: These are common self-soothing behaviors, but they can be harmful if they injure your skin. To stop them, you need to be very aware of when you do it and replace the habit with a healthier one. Awareness: Figure out your triggers (is it stress? boredom? homework?). Replacement: Whenever you feel the urge, use a 'competing response.' Instead of scratching, try: Squeezing a stress ball, Fidgeting with a tangle toy, Holding an ice cube, or Doodling in a notebook. This keeps your hands busy and redirects the nervous energy into a harmless activity.

instruction: I am afraid to speak up and participate in class because I worry that the other students will judge my answer. How can I build confidence to talk in front of people?
output: The fear of being judged is strong, but you have valuable ideas to share! To build confidence, start with small, low-risk steps: 1. Practice at home: Read a homework answer out loud to a parent or friend first. 2. Aim for one small contribution: Set a goal to say just one sentence in class that isn't a full answer (e.g., 'I agree with [peer's name] because...'). 3. Reframe the feeling: When you feel nervous, acknowledge it: 'I feel nervous, and that's okay.' Remind yourself that other people are likely focused on their own fears, not on judging you. Each time you speak up, your confidence will grow!

instruction: I have a lot of emotions all at once, and I don't know how to calm myself down. What are some fast ways to settle my feelings?
output: When emotions are overwhelming, you need to 'hit the reset button' for your nervous system. Try the TIPP skills from Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT): T: Tip the Temperature (Hold an ice cube or splash cold water on your face). I: Intense Exercise (Do 60 seconds of jumping jacks or running in place). P: Paced Breathing (Breathe in for 4, hold for 4, out for 6). P: Paired Muscle Relaxation (Tense a muscle group for 5 seconds, then relax completely). These physical techniques are very effective at quickly calming your body, which then calms your mind.

instruction: My older sister is going off to college, and I feel abandoned and sad that she won't be here. How do I adjust to her leaving?
output: The feeling of sadness and abandonment is real and understandable; your sister is a major part of your daily life. It is natural to grieve her absence.
